data.title: Jackie Kennedyâ€™s strange, elegant accent, explained by linguists
data.meta_description: Why Natalie Portmanâ€™s accent in Jackie is spot-on, even though it may sound odd to many people.
data.text:
The first time Natalie Portman speaks in Jackie, Noah Oppenheimâ€™s arthouse semi-biopic about former first lady Jackie Kennedy Onassis, is three minutes into the movie. Itâ€™s a week after John F. Kennedyâ€™s assassination, and a journalist from Life magazine has come to the Kennedysâ€™ home in Hyannis Port, Massachusetts, to interview her. He offers his condolences.

Portman, a startling amalgam of cheekbones, sharp brows, and a thicket of root beer-colored hair, lets out a breathy, biting rebuke.

â€œHave you read what they've been writing? Krock and Merriman and all the rest?â€ she snaps, referring to journalists Arthur Krock and Merriman Smith. â€œMerriman is such a bitter man. It's been just one week and already theyâ€™re treating him like some dusty old artifact, to be shelved away. Thatâ€™s no way to be remembered.â€

Merely reading that line doesnâ€™t do justice to the voice Portman adopted for the role. If youâ€™re not aware of how Jackie Kennedy spoke, listening to Portmanâ€™s Jackie is like the tingle of soda in your throat. It often feels familiar, but in certain spots it pops and jumps. The way she lops off the end of â€œbitter,â€ the funny hop in â€œartifact,â€ the way she rolls through â€œrememberedâ€ â€” itâ€™s like sheâ€™s invented her own unique way of speaking English:

But Portmanâ€™s delivery is accurate in the way it captures the former first ladyâ€™s affect. And that might be the most impressive element of her Oscar-nominated performance.

Jackie Kennedy will always be an American icon; her style was impossibly chic, her beauty is immortal, and her poise and grace in the aftermath of tragedy will never be forgotten. Embodying any of those characteristics onscreen is no small feat. But itâ€™s Kennedyâ€™s distinctive voice â€” a peculiar drawl that defies simple linguistic classification â€” that presents the greatest challenge for any actress who might attempt to imitate her.

Jackie Kennedy spoke like an old-time New Yorker â€¦ sort of

When linguists study accents and dialects, they listen for â€œfeaturesâ€ that help differentiate one speaking style or characteristic from the next. In this case, the term refers to how certain words and vowels are pronounced; they are what makes certain accents stand out or sound strange if weâ€™re not used to them. Kennedyâ€™s accent contains several different features, but according to several linguists I spoke to for this story, the most pronounced ones are â€œnon-rhoticity,â€ which is also called â€œR-lessness,â€ and a â€œsplit short A system.â€

Non-rhoticity is generally heard in Northeast and Southern accents, and particularly in older people who were born before WWII, since itâ€™s a feature they grew up with. In plain English, itâ€™s when someone drops the â€œRâ€ sound in words like â€œbarâ€ and â€œguardian,â€ pronouncing them â€œbahâ€ and â€œgahdian.â€ A recent pop culture example: Kevin Spaceyâ€™s Frank Underwood on the Netflix series House of Cards:

The non-rhoticity feature originated in England, whose different regional dialects display a mix of rhoticity (where people pronounced their words with Râ€™s intact) and non-rhoticity (where people drop their Râ€™s). When different groups of English immigrants settled in the United States in the 1800s and earlier, some brought over the non-rhotic affectation â€” typically to the metropolitan areas that are now Boston and New York City, as well as the South â€” and some brought over the rhotic affectation. For a period of time prior to WWII, non-rhoticity was also considered posh or fashionable because of its origins in Britain.

The linguists I spoke with explained that Jackie Kennedyâ€™s accent is at least partially typical of someone with her upbringing, in that it tracks with her early childhood in Southampton in the 1930s but was clearly influenced by going to school in Manhattan and spending a lot of time there growing up.

â€œYou don't hear some of those stereotypical New York features in her accent, but you do hear that R-lessness,â€ says Anne Marie Olivo-Shaw, a linguistics PhD who researched and wrote her dissertation on New York City English dialect among different ethnic groups on Long Island, New York.

Olivo-Shaw explained that there are other features heard on Long Island and in New York City like the â€œcawffeeâ€ vowel, and the â€œeâ€ vowel. The â€œcawffeeâ€ vowel turns the vowel sound in the word â€œcoffeeâ€ and similar words into more of aw-sound. The latter turns the word â€œmeâ€ into something closer to â€œmayâ€ or â€œmae.â€

For Olivo-Shaw, the feature of Kennedyâ€™s accent that most stood out was R-lessness.

â€œShe says â€˜the cahâ€™ [instead of â€˜the carâ€™] and â€˜fine ahtsâ€™ [instead of â€˜fine artsâ€™],â€ Olivo-Shaw explained.

But there are also curious wrinkles.

â€œI also noticed that she dropped her Râ€™s in a place where not all New Yorkers do â€” itâ€™s an extreme place to drop your Râ€™s,â€ said Kara Becker, an assistant professor of linguistics at Reed College told me. Becker studies the New York City accent.

â€œItâ€™s when she has an â€œerrâ€ sound thatâ€™s stressed in a word. So a word like â€˜furniture,â€™ a lot of people who drop their Râ€™s wouldnâ€™t drop them there, but she did. So you get â€˜fuhnituh.â€™â€

The other particularly noticeable feature of Kennedyâ€™s accent is a â€œsplit short A system.â€ Both Becker and Olivo-Shaw defined it as the short A vowel sound changing in words where youâ€™d think it would be similar.

â€œThe split short A system happens across the Northeast, but it's very specific in different regions. So in New York it happens in words like â€˜batâ€™ versus â€˜bad,â€™ [where â€˜badâ€™ can sound closer to â€˜bedâ€™ if thereâ€™s a split system],â€ Olivo-Shaw said. "Kennedy says â€˜kehntâ€™ instead of â€˜canâ€™t.â€™â€

You can also hear it in the way Kennedy says the word â€œback.â€

â€œWe [linguists] talk about vowels in where theyâ€™re produced in the mouth,â€ Becker explained, noting that Kennedy has an extreme case of this. â€œHer tongue is in the back of her mouth when the word â€˜back.â€™â€

Try pulling your tongue into the back of your mouth and saying â€œbackâ€ or â€œpass.â€ It changes the A vowel sound, so that you make less of an â€œackâ€ or â€œassâ€ sound; instead, it sounds a bit rounder. If you pull your tongue forward in your mouth, and try it again, it changes the word.

Kennedyâ€™s R-lessness and split short A system are not only regionally specific, but historically specific, because characteristics like R-lessness have slowly faded from New York accents over time. According to linguists, there was a shift around World War II where features like R-lessness started to become less pronounced. Because R-lessness isnâ€™t as common or as conspicuous as it used to be, its presence in Kennedyâ€™s accent can make her sound especially unusual to younger generations.

â€œSo some people might have none of the features of New York City English, but then they might have a split short A system, which is actually pretty common,â€ Olivo-Shaw said. â€œAnd among the younger people, they don't have as many of the features in general as older generations do.â€

Jackie Kennedy was affluent, and her wealth is reflected in the way she speaks

Thereâ€™s a rule of thumb in linguistics that you tend to see a higher number of pronounced features in working-class people than affluent people. But during Kennedyâ€™s time â€” from her childhood in the â€™30s into her adulthood â€” upper-class individuals in the Northeast exhibited certain speech patterns, often taught in expensive private schools, that combined elements of British English and American English, resulting in what is sometimes called a â€œprestigeâ€ accent (itâ€™s also known as Mid-Atlantic prestige accent, and colloquially as the â€œBoston Brahminâ€ or the â€œLocust Valley Lockjawâ€) .

This accent was characterized by a distinct pronunciation that sounds like a mix between British and American English.

â€œPeople in private school, people of a certain social class, thatâ€™s the way they talked,â€ Rebecca Babcock, a professor at University of Texas of the Permian Basin, told me. â€œIt has an upper class, or an upper-crust â€” they call it an index.â€

Babcock is an expert in sociolinguistics, and cites Franklin Delano Roosevelt and John Kerry (in his earlier speeches) as examples of people who speak with this prestige index, but explains that it has also appeared in pop culture when people want to create a character who appears to be intellectual or well-to-do, like Effie Trinket in The Hunger Games and Stewie from Family Guy.

Babcock says that what stood out to her about Kennedy, in addition to the first ladyâ€™s accent, was her grammatical formality. Kennedy, whenever she appeared on television, always sounded very proper, often formalizing her language by saying â€œoneâ€ where most of us would say â€œyou.â€

â€œOne has to pay attention to oneâ€™s speech to use â€˜one,â€™â€ Babcock told me, emphasizing the stateliness and perhaps awkwardness of saying â€œoneâ€ in a two-person conversation. â€œThe natural is to say â€˜you.â€™ So that sort of grammar â€” thatâ€™s a careful use of proper grammar.â€

But Babcock noted that Kennedyâ€™s adherence to formality wasnâ€™t consistent, and that instead of saying the phrase â€œgoing to,â€ which is what one would expect considering Kennedyâ€™s fondness for proper grammar, Kennedy used the word â€œgonna.â€

â€œPeople donâ€™t 100 percent of the time use 100 percent of all the features of whatever dialect theyâ€™re speaking,â€ Babcock said. â€œItâ€™s variable.â€

And Becker connected some of the nuances of Kennedyâ€™s speech, like the way she pronounces â€œfurnitureâ€ or splits her Aâ€™s, to what she was likely taught as a child and the affluent social circles she was part of.

â€œOne thing she does a lot is aspirate her Tâ€™s. If you have a T at the end of a word, most Americans donâ€™t produce a puff of air, but you can. She does this a lot,â€ Becker said explaining that when Kennedy would say words like â€œcanâ€™tâ€ and â€œbut,â€ youâ€™d hear a little breath that almost sounds like a split-second gasp or an â€œuhâ€ sound.

According to Becker, aspirated Tâ€™s link Kennedyâ€™s accent more to her affluent background than to a specific place.

Jackie Kennedy was a politician, and politicians often change their accents to match their audience

When Portman was asked how she learned Kennedyâ€™s accent, the actress told the Los Angeles Times that she looked up every interview with Kennedy that she could find on YouTube and watched the first ladyâ€™s 1962 White House Tour over and over.

Itâ€™s important to note that Kennedyâ€™s White House Tour, as well as much of the archival footage we have of Jackie Kennedy, first aired on broadcast TV. That means that when Kennedy was filming an interview, for example, she would have known that itâ€™d be seen by people all across the country.

As Babcock stated above, no one speaks with 100 percent of their features 100 percent of the time. Humans change the way they speak based on the situation theyâ€™re in and who theyâ€™re speaking to; think about how some people tend to speak with more of an accent when they visit their hometowns, or the way we sometimes speak differently at work versus at home.

Theoretically, if people shift their vocal patterns based on who theyâ€™re speaking to, then a situation where Kennedy was speaking on television would no doubt shift the way she, and other first ladies and politicians, spoke. Political figures, after all, have to convince the people theyâ€™re talking to to believe in them and support them, and thatâ€™s hard to do if you sound like an outsider.

Politicians fine-tuning their speech for their audiences happens all the time. Barack Obamaâ€™s speeches have been analyzed for their cadence, and linguists have examined President Donald Trumpâ€™s speaking patterns at length.

If thereâ€™s one thing in particular that Jackie wants to convey, itâ€™s that no one knew the power of image in politics like Jackie Kennedy. Quite simply: She knew how to present herself, and that includes how she sounded.

â€œJackie's tone was very quiet, very breathy,â€ Babcock said (Babcock also explained that her one issue with Portmanâ€™s delivery is that she delivers it with a â€œcreaky voiceâ€ affectation and less breath). â€œThat is also a cultured way of speaking. And of course that was also taught because a â€˜ladyâ€™ at that time would speak in a soft, cultured, and very clear way.â€

Kennedy was fully aware of how important her public appearances were in terms of how she was perceived. Leaning into certain features of her accent, while mitigating others, could account for the more curious and inconsistent pockets of her speech â€” like the way she formalizes the â€œyouâ€ by saying â€œoneâ€ instead. And the moments when she does break with formality could be her way of trying to be appear more approachable. While we canâ€™t know for certain how Kennedy made her grammatical choices, Babcock stressed that her public interviews were probably rehearsed backward and forward, and that Kennedy, again like many politicians, was prepped on how to appear.

The linguists I talked to all explained that Kennedyâ€™s accent is something of a rarity today. Back then, it might have been a rarity too, unless you floated in the same upper-crust circles she did.

Today, you may be able to find older New Yorkers and New Englanders who speak with Kennedyâ€™s soft, rolling intonation laced with the prim touches of finishing school. But it wonâ€™t be super easy. Thatâ€™s why younger generations might not be familiar with what she sounded like; to many people, sheâ€™s just that glamorous first lady they read about in textbooks. And thatâ€™s part of the magic of watching Portmanâ€™s performance in Jackie â€” learning something new about someone we thought we knew. Capturing Kennedyâ€™s voice was an essential part of bringing the movie to life.
